awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Detecting and Controlling Network-based Spread of Hospital Acquired Infections
awd_abstract_narration:
Hospital Acquired Infections (HAIs) are becoming a major challenge in health systems worldwide. Detection and control of HAIs are challenging and resource intensive, because of the high costs of patient treatment and disinfection of hospital facilities, making them fundamental public health problems. Despite its huge importance for hospitals, and the interest from both clinical and epidemiological researchers, these problems remain poorly understood. This project seeks to develop a novel network-based approach to improve hospital infection control using models and data science. This proposal brings together a highly multi-disciplinary team of researchers, and will lead to fundamental contributions in different areas of computer science (data mining, machine learning, graph mining, social networks, and optimization), network science (mathematical models and dynamical systems) and computational epidemiology (infectious diseases, and hospital epidemiology). The planned work has immediate implications for public health e.g. it can lead to new design policies and guidance for hospital infection control. Research findings will be incorporated into graduate level classes, tutorials, contests and workshops to bring computational biologists and data miners together. 

There are several challenges in studying HAI outbreaks primarily because the dynamics of HAI spread are much more complex than other diseases, such as influenza, due to many more factors and pathways involved. To overcome these issues, the project team will use a new class of two-mode cascade models, which have very different dynamics than the standard models, and have not been studied in data mining. The will investigate the following topics: (1) Surveillance, early detection of HAI outbreaks, (2) Designing interventions to control the spread of HAIs, and (3) Modeling and estimating exposure risk for HAIs. A unified set of problems will be considered, including modeling, detection, control and inference of missing infections. These are challenging stochastic optimization problems on networks, and the project team will invent rigorous and scalable methods using tools from data mining, machine learning and combinatorial optimization. Their research will use a unique fine-grained, large-scale data set of operations from a public hospital, supplemented with data from other hospitals. The results will be validated with the help of domain experts including epidemiologists and clinicians involved in hospital infection control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hospital Acquired Infections (HAIs) such as C.Diff and MRSA are a major challenge in today's healthcare systems worldwide; many of these infections are becoming resistant to antibiotics, which makes their treatment very difficult. Detection and control of HAIs are challenging and resource intensive, because of the high costs of patient treatment and disinfection of hospital facilities, making them fundamental public health problems. In this project, we combine a modeling-based approach with a data-driven approach to address inference and control problems for HAIs. Computational modeling provides the foundation for our work. We have designed and formalized a load sharing model for the spread of fomite-based infections in healthcare settings. We believe this is the first mathematical model for fomite-based infections and it can now be studied both mathematically and computationally. We have established fundamental properties (e.g., submodularity, epidemic threshold) for this and other related models of HAI spread. This load sharing model serves as the basis for the formulation of inference and mitigation problems for HAIs, e.g., inferring asymptomatic cases, inferring infection sources, mitigating HAIs by vaccination, etc., as combinatorial optimization problems. For example, we formulate the problem of inferring asymptomatic cases as the prize-collecting Steiner tree problem. For these problems, we provide algorithmic solutions, with provable worst case approximation guarantees as well as scalable performance. This theoretical work is complemented by computational experiments that show that our algorithms are superior to a variety of baselines. Our experiments use a unique fine-grained, large-scale data set of hospital operations gathered over the last 10 years from the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics. This dataset integrates novel sources of data---detailed healthcare worker mobility from sensors, electronic health records (EHR), CAD drawings, pharmacy data, and disease incidence data. Our experimental results have been vetted by domain experts -- epidemiologists and clinicians at the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics. We have also presented a lot of this work to members of the CDC MInD Healthcare Network; feedback from this group of experts has also been incorporated into our work.
  

A key contribution of our work is a mathematical model (i.e., a load sharing model) for HAI spread. This model is being analyzed by domain experts at Iowa as well as other institutions and is the basis for hypotheses that can be tested in future projects via field experiments in healthcare settings. This project has provided training and mentoring to 4 PhD students, 2 Masters students, 2 undergraduate students, and 1 high school student. Results from this project have formed the bulk of the dissertation of a PhD student who graduated in the fall of 2023. Our participation in this project has helped the Dept of Computer Science at the University of Iowa become a NSF REU site for a project titled "Computing for Health and Well being". Our group mentored two undergraduate students on projects related to this proposal as part of the REU in Summer 2021, 5 REU students in Summer 2022, and 6 students in Summer 2023. PIs have also taught a "Computational Epidemiology" course aimed at seniors and beginning graduate students.
